choices.text: Rapidly dividing cells are resistant to radiation
GI mucosa is one of the most radioresistant tissues in the body
The intensity of Radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
Small blood vessels are least resistant to radiation

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding radiation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The inverse square law states that radiation intensity decreases with the square of the distance from the source, critical for radiation safety.
  • Rapidly dividing cells (Option A) are radiosensitive due to active DNA replication.
  • GI mucosa (Option B) is radiosensitive and not resistant.
  • Small blood vessels (Option D) are relatively radioresistant but not universally so.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with metastatic breast cancer is being evaluated for radionuclide therapy. The oncologist chooses a radioisotope that emits radiation capable of deep tissue penetration to effectively target deep-seated lesions. Which of the following types of radiation is most suitable for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gamma rays have the highest penetration power among all listed radiation types, making them suitable for imaging and treatment of deep-seated tissues.

  • Gamma Rays:
    • Gamma rays, high-energy electromagnetic radiation, penetrate deeply, making them suitable for imaging and some therapeutic applications.
    • Gamma-emitting isotopes like Iodine-131 and Technetium-99m are preferred when deeper tissue or systemic targeting is needed.
  • Maximum penetration: neutron > γ > β > α rays
  • Maximum ionisation: α > β > γ rays.

Explanation of other options:

Alpha particles (Option A) have low penetration (stopped by skin).

Beta particles (Option B) penetrate a few millimetres, suitable for superficial tumours.

Electron beams (Option D) are used in external radiotherapy for superficial targets.

choices.text: Ultrasonography to detect hyperechoic foreign bodies with posterior shadowing
MRI for its superior soft tissue contrast and foreign body localisation
CT scan due to its high sensitivity for all types of foreign materials
Plain radiograph to detect radiopaque foreign bodies like glass

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with pain and swelling over the tip of the left index finger after an injury while playing with a broken glass. On examination, the fingertip is swollen and tender, with no obvious retained foreign body seen externally. You suspect a retained glass fragment. Which of the following imaging modalities is the most appropriate initial investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Plain radiographs are the first-line imaging modality for detecting radiopaque foreign bodies like glass, which appear as high-density objects.

  • The choice of imaging for foreign body detection depends on the composition of the material.
  • Glass is radiopaque in most cases, and even small fragments can be identified on a standard X-ray. Hence, a plain radiograph is the initial investigation of choice, particularly for superficial injuries where clinical suspicion is high.
  • It avoids unnecessary costs and radiation from CT or the contraindications of MRI.
  • While CT is more sensitive for radiolucent foreign bodies or very small glass fragments, it is not used initially unless the X-ray is negative and suspicion remains high. (Option C ruled out)
  • Ultrasound is useful for radiolucent organic materials like wood, but not preferred initially for suspected glass. (Option A ruled out)
  • MRI is generally avoided in the setting of a potential metallic or uncertain foreign body due to the risk of artefact or movement. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following units is used to measure the radiation dose in CT imaging?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Millisievert (mSv) measures the effective radiation dose in CT imaging, reflecting the biological risk of radiation exposure.

Explanation of other options:

Gray (Option A) measures the absorbed dose.

Sievert (Option B) measures the equivalent dose.

Hounsfield Units (Option C) measure radiodensity.

questions.text: A 29-year-old radiology technician discovers she is pregnant while working in a diagnostic imaging department. She informs her radiation safety officer immediately. According to AERB guidelines, what is the maximum permissible radiation dose to the fetus during the entire pregnancy for occupational exposure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

AERB and ICRP guidelines limit fetal radiation exposure to 1 mSv during the entire pregnancy to minimise risks of congenital abnormalities and cancer.

  • Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) in India, in alignment with International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP) recommendations, mandates that once a pregnancy is declared, the exposure to the fetus (conceptus) should not exceed 1 mSv for the remainder of the pregnancy.
  • This is to minimize the risk of deterministic effects (such as growth retardation or congenital abnormalities) and stochastic effects (like cancer).
  • Pregnant radiation workers should also be reassigned to lower exposure areas and wear abdominal dosimeters to monitor fetal exposure.

questions.text: Which of the following devices is routinely used to monitor cumulative radiation exposure in healthcare workers involved in diagnostic imaging or radiation therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

TLD badges are personal dosimeters that measure and record cumulative occupational radiation exposure in healthcare workers.

TLD Badge:

  • TLD badges contain crystals (commonly lithium fluoride) that absorb radiation and later release the stored energy as light when heated.
  • The amount of light emitted correlates with the radiation dose received.
  • These are worn by radiology, nuclear medicine, and radiotherapy workers, typically at chest or waist level, and are analysed monthly or quarterly to ensure doses stay within AERB-recommended limits (e.g., 20 mSv/year for whole-body exposure).
  • TLDs help monitor chronic occupational exposure and ensure compliance with radiation safety standards.

Explanation of other options:

Linear Accelerator (Option B) is used for producing X-rays, not for dose monitoring in occupational workers.

Collimators (Option C) are used in X-ray tubes to reduce the scattering, not for the dose monitoring in occupational workers.

Grid (Option D) is used in X-ray films, not for dose monitoring in occupational workers.

Reference:
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17681962/

choices.text: During menstruation or within the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle
Between days 14 and 20 of the menstrual cycle
After ovulation but before the next period
Any time in the cycle, as long as pregnancy is ruled out by a urine test

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with right lower quadrant pain, and the clinician suspects appendicitis. Before ordering a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen, you note that she is in the reproductive age group. According to radiation safety guidelines, when should high-radiation imaging (like CT or fluoroscopy) ideally be scheduled to minimise fetal risk?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The 10-day rule recommends scheduling high-radiation imaging (e.g., CT) within the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle when pregnancy is unlikely.

  • The "10-day rule" is a radiation protection principle that advises scheduling non-urgent radiological procedures involving ionising radiation during the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle (from the onset of menstruation), because fertilisation and implantation have not yet occurred, minimising the risk of inadvertently irradiating a conceptus.
  • This is especially important when imaging involves high radiation exposure (e.g., CT abdomen/pelvis, fluoroscopy, interventional radiology).

Explanation of other options:

Between days 14 and 20 of the menstrual cycle (Option B): Day 14-20 corresponds to the peri-ovulatory phase, when pregnancy risk is highest.

After ovulation but before the next period (Option C): Post-ovulatory phase carries a significant risk of early pregnancy and should be avoided for radiation exposure.

Any time in the cycle, as long as pregnancy is ruled out by a urine test (Option D): While pregnancy tests help, the 10-day rule remains a safer and more standardised approach for scheduling.

questions.text: In the context of radiology and medical imaging, what does the acronym PACS stand for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

PACS (Picture Archiving and Communication System) is a digital system for storing, retrieving, and transmitting medical images (e.g., CT, MRI). It enhances workflow and supports teleradiology.

Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS)

  • PACS is a key component in modern radiology departments, enabling the digital storage, retrieval, transmission, and display of medical images from modalities such as CT, MRI, X-ray, and ultrasound.
  • It integrates with Hospital Information Systems (HIS) and Radiology Information Systems (RIS) and allows radiologists and clinicians to access images from any networked location, improving workflow, reducing film usage, and facilitating teleradiology.
  • It is essential for achieving filmless radiology and plays a critical role in diagnostic accuracy and efficiency.
  • A few acronyms in radiology are:
    • ALARA: As Low as Reasonably Achievable
    • DICOM: Digital Imaging and Communication in Medicine
    • PACS: Picture Archiving and Communication System
    • POCUS: Point of care ultrasound

questions.text: Among the following radiological investigations, which typically involves the highest radiation dose to the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Barium enema delivers the highest effective dose (~7-8 mSv) due to prolonged fluoroscopy and multiple radiographs.

  • Radiation dose in diagnostic imaging varies by technique, duration, and area irradiated.
  • Barium enema requires extended fluoroscopy time, often with multiple spot films covering the abdomen and pelvis, resulting in a relatively high effective dose (approx. 7-8 mSv).
  • In comparison,
    • CT head has a lower dose (~1-2 mSv) (Options A)
    • IVU (Intravenous Urography) delivers moderate radiation (~2-3 mSv) (Options B)
    • Bone scans, typically deliver a lower effective dose (~4-5 mSv) (Options D)
